newsitem.title: USA: U.N. approves discounts in Mar for Iraq crude.
newsitem.headline: U.N. approves discounts in Mar for Iraq crude.

text.p: The United Nations sanctions committee on Iraq has approved an extension through the whole of March of the special discount price for Iraqi crude to U.S. customers, diplomats said Friday.
Also, the committee approved a 25 cents a barrel cut in prices to Europe for shipments covering most of March, the diplomatic sources said.
Iraq, under its "oil-for-food" deal with the United Nations, currently has 37 contracts with oil companies, most of which are European or American.
Weak markets for sour crude in the U.S. led to a special cut in Iraq's Basrah Light crude in February to a discount of $4.30 under benchmark front-month West Texas Intermediate/Cushing.

That price was to have applied to oil lifted for U.S. customers in February and up to March 10. But the continued soft markets led the sanctions committee to approve a request by Iraq's State Oil Marketing Organization (SOMO) to extend that price through to the end of March.
Also, the sanctions committee approved a 25 cents a barrel cut in prices for Kirkuk Blend crude to Europe from March 10 to $1.80 a barrel under North Sea Brent blend.
The sanctions committee also agreed that April prices for Iraq crude would come down in line with those of Saudi Arab Light prices.
Though Iraqi crude is priced against regional benchmarks WTI for the U.S., Brent for Europe and South Africa and Oman/Dubai for the Far East, it effectively tracks the movements Arab Light.
The committee also agreed in February to change the U.S. benchmark for Iraq to the second-month WTI contract from March 10 but this will take effect now in April.
April Basrah to the U.S. will be priced at $4.05 a barrel under the second-month WTI price and Kirkuk at $3.50 under, reflecting a cut in April Arab Light of 15 cents to the U.S.
Basrah prices to Europe and South Africa are both cut 10 cents in April, while the Far East differential was left unchanged.
